project_card_fields.ProjectRole:
Based on the detailed **Context** provided, the role being requested is that of an **Owner’s Engineer (or Implementation Consultant)** — specifically, a **third-party independent consultant engaged by the project owner (or implementing agency, such as PMU) to oversee, advise, and ensure the successful execution of the rehabilitation project**.

### Here's a breakdown of why this is the case:

---

### ✅ **1. Role: Owner’s Engineer / Implementation Consultant**
The document explicitly refers to the entity as the **"Implementation Consultant (IC)"**, which is a standard term used in development finance (e.g., by the Asian Development Bank - ADB) for an independent consultant hired by the **project owner or implementing agency (PMU)** to:
- Assess project feasibility and condition,
- Prepare technical and procurement documents,
- Support tendering and contractor selection,
- Monitor implementation,
- Ensure compliance with donor (ADB) standards and grant agreements,
- Report to the owner and donor.

This is **not** an EPC (Engineering, Procurement, Construction) designer, nor is it a lender’s engineer.

---

### ❌ **Not EPC Designer**
- The IC is **not responsible for designing the project as a contractor**.
- The IC **prepares design criteria and scope**, but **does not execute the construction**.
- The actual design and construction will be done by **bidders (EPC contractors)** selected through a competitive process.
- The IC **reviews** the EPC designs but does **not produce them**.

> Example: “The IC will carry out a detailed assessment of the condition of the switchyards and will submit a Design Report...” — this is advisory, not execution.

---

### ❌ **Not Lender’s Engineer**
- While the IC reports to ADB (the lender), it is **not acting as the lender’s representative** in a financial or risk-monitoring capacity.
- The IC’s role is **technical and project implementation-focused**, not financial due diligence or loan servicing.
- Lender’s engineers typically focus on **financial risk, disbursement controls, and loan compliance**, whereas this IC is focused on **technical quality, design, procurement, and construction oversight**.

> Example: The IC prepares reports for ADB, but its primary client is the **PMU (Project Management Unit)**, which is the project owner.

---

### ✅ **Key Indicators of Owner’s Engineer Role:**

| Feature | Evidence from Context |
|-------|------------------------|
| **Independent oversight** | The IC is not part of the construction team; it advises the PMU and ADB. |
| **Design & procurement support** | Prepares bid documents, evaluates bids, assists in contractor selection. |
| **Monitoring & reporting** | Monthly/quarterly progress reports, safety, quality, environmental monitoring. |
| **Technical review** | Reviews contractor designs (e.g., C&P, SCADA, gates), ensures compliance. |
| **Client: PMU (project owner)** | The IC works for PMU, not the contractor or lender. |
| **ADB compliance** | Reports to ADB, follows ADB procurement and monitoring frameworks. |

---

### ✅ **Conclusion:**
> The requested role is that of an **Owner’s Engineer (or Implementation Consultant)** — an independent technical advisor hired by the **project owner (PMU)** to ensure the **technical quality, compliance, and successful delivery** of the rehabilitation project, particularly under **ADB funding and oversight**.

This role is **not** EPC design, nor is it a lender’s engineer — it is a **project implementation and quality assurance function** on behalf of the **owner**.

---

### Summary:
> **Role Requested:** **Owner’s Engineer (Implementation Consultant)**  
> **Client:** Project Management Unit (PMU)  
> **Donor Oversight:** Asian Development Bank (ADB)  
> **Key Responsibilities:** Technical assessment, design preparation, procurement support, contractor evaluation, construction monitoring, reporting, compliance with ADB standards.
project_card_fields.Project Scope:
Phase: Construction supervision and contract administration  
Scope: Implementation of two contracts — Powerhouse rehabilitation and Switchyard rehabilitation — including design review, bid preparation, contractor selection assistance, construction supervision, quality and schedule control, safety coordination, environmental monitoring, and project reporting.
